summary: This is an official transcript from a probate court hearing in the Superior Court of the Virgin Islands regarding the estate of Jeffrey E. Epstein. The hearing focuses on motions related to the estate administration, including the appointment of appraisers and a master, fee applications, quarterly accountings, and a claims resolution program for victims. Kenneth Feinberg testifies as an expert witness about the proposed victim compensation program.

connections.description: Attorney Tomback conducts the direct examination of witness Kenneth Feinberg during the court hearing.
Feinberg states that he and Ms. Biros together received assurances from the Epstein estate regarding the independence of the victim compensation program.
Both attorneys are listed as appearing on behalf of the Co-Executors of the Epstein estate.
Feinberg is the proposed administrator of a victim compensation program funded by the Epstein estate.
Ms. George, representing the Virgin Islands government, has raised multiple criticisms and concerns about the victim compensation program Feinberg is proposing to administer.

events.title: Court Order Signed by Justice Cabret
events.description: An order related to the probate proceedings was approved and signed by Justice Cabret.

events.title: Oath Attested by Clerk
events.description: An oath was attested by the Clerk of the Court, Attorney Handy.

events.title: Probate Court Hearing
events.description: Hearing before Magistrate Judge Carolyn P. H. Percell regarding motions in the Epstein estate probate case, including testimony from Kenneth Feinberg on a proposed victim compensation program.

events.title: Filing of Civil Lawsuit by Virgin Islands AG
events.description: The Attorney General of the United States Virgin Islands filed a civil lawsuit in another court, which is referenced during the hearing.

locations: Superior Court of the Virgin Islands, Division of St. Thomas/St. John
GERS Building, Second Floor, St. Thomas, Virgin Islands
keyFacts: A victim compensation program is being proposed for the Epstein estate, to be administered independently by Kenneth Feinberg.
The program is designed to be confidential and non-adversarial, with the estate having no authority to reject or modify the administrator's determinations on claims.
The Virgin Islands Attorney General (Ms. George) has raised significant concerns about the program, including potential conflicts of interest and the scope of releases required from claimants.
Kenneth Feinberg testified that the program would protect claimant confidentiality and not share information with the estate or law enforcement, respecting claimants' wishes.
The hearing addressed multiple motions including the appointment of appraisers and a master, fee applications, quarterly accountings, and the claims resolution program.
